Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Unraveling the Limits of Computation in Structural and Infrastructure Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project identifies structural and infrastructure engineering (SIE) metrics and explores analytical and simulation methods that quantify these metrics. SIE metrics studied in this research include: reliability, robustness, redundancy, resilience, risk, sustainability, and life-cycle cost. Given that these metrics have different semantic perspectives their quantification has not been explored using computational and algorithmic thinking while this research does so. The research also studies the computational limits for each metric and takes advantage of the opportunities for exact and approximate formulations. Computable metrics inform the practice of designing, building, maintenance, and restoration of SIE systems. In addition, the research involves a diverse pool of students for which computational algorithms will be a mechanism for the design of SIE systems.

A taxonomy of metrics for SIE applications is explored, while demonstrating via mathematical proofs the membership of these metrics to a computational complexity hierarchy. Proofs are mainly achieved via reducible chains in polynomial time, special subroutines such as oracles, while combinatorial arguments reveal which metrics to pursue using diverse strategies, either exactly or approximately. For instance, the research explores recursive formulations for metrics at the bottom of the hierarchy, and additional proofs are pursued to determine why practical constraints, such as correlations in reliability, break the structure of the problem into exponential time algorithms. The project explores symmetries, periodicities, and other features that support probabilistic algorithms with tolerances and confidence levels that are acceptable for large SIE problem instances.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The impact of the work that resulted from the grant Collaborative Research: Unraveling the Limits of Computation in Structural and Infrastructure Engineering has been twofold. In terms of the research impact, the project produced novel results in the analysis of the reliability of complex systems with especial emphasis on the modeling of the stochastic behavior of the power grid. The project also nurtured and encouraged the development of human resources, especially from students from underrepresented populations, by producing a cadre of students who are currently pursuing graduate degrees in the statistical and data sciences fields.

Research: In the paper Quantum-Inspired Boolean States for Bounding Engineering Network Reliability Assessment, co-authored with Leonardo Duenas-Osorio and Moshe Vardi– soon to appear in Structural Safety– novel work is presented using quantum computing and probabilistic ideas to provide a technique to bound network reliability. The technique hinges on a multidisciplinary approach to count the number of configurations for the network satisfiability problem. This new approach provides alternatives to the classical system reliability methodologies an has, potentially, opens up new direction for research that can benefit from new developments in quantum computing, logic, and algebraic projections.

In addition, several works are in progress, and will soon be submitted, that are extending the results of Dueñas-Osorio and Rojo (2011) to cases that incorporate geo-spatial information and association among the various power grid components. These new models capture more realistic settings and provide algorithms to compute power grid reliabilities.

These results have the potential to impact the ability to predict, and react accordingly, to events that may negatively and substantially affect several important aspects of our daily lives. Being able to take corrective actions in time to minimize theimpact of a potential blackout will save lives and billions of dollars to the US economy.

Human resources development: Through the REU Program RUSIS@OSU, the collaborative research has developed new human resources interested in further researching the various approaches discussed during the REU projects. The REU program already has 25 Ph.D. alumni who have taken positions in institutions such as Johns Hopkins, University of Arizona, ETH Zürich, Eli Lily etc. It is expected that these students will, in turn, nurture the development of new human resources in these areas.
